newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian Telenet to start in 1998, CEO says.
newsitem.headline: Belgian Telenet to start in 1998, CEO says.

text.p: Belgian telecommunications group Telenet, which aims to convert Flanders' cable television network to provide multimedia and voice telephone services, will become operational in 1998, its chief executive officer said.

"We prefer to keep a low profile, because Telenet has nothing to offer at the moment. It is not until 1998 that we will offer our first services," Telenet CEO Paul Van der Spiegel told Belgian daily Le Soir in an interview.
He added, however, that a limited number of clients in the Flemish towns of Antwerp and Mechelen could be offered trial Internet services in autumn 1997.
He also said that it would take another four and a half years before all Flemish homes would be connected to its fibre-optics network.
Once the Flemish network is operational, Telenet will also start marketing its services in Brussels and in Wallonia.
Telenet has no ambition to become the operator of a third mobile telephone network, Van der Spiegel said. Belgium is expected to offer a third mobile phone licence next year.
Telenet Operaties NV is a unit of Telenet Holding NV, which is 25 percent-owned by U.S. West International and 20 percent by Flander's publicly-owned investment company GIMV.
